docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has proposed welcome new rules that would make it a lot easier for consumers to compare one health insurance policy with another before signing up.

headline.seo: Penetrating the Gibberish of Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Editorial notes the Obama administration has proposed new rules that will make it easier for consumers to compare health insurance policies before signing up; asserts insurers' objections to the rules are ridiculous; argues relatively small cost burden on the industry for complying with the rules would provide a huge benefit for consumers and help spur competition to bring down health insurance costs.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration has proposed welcome new rules that would make it a lot easier for consumers to compare one health insurance policy with another before signing up.

docs.lead_paragraph: In small-town Oregon, it’s easy to spot the country’s most pressing problem.

headline.seo: Did We Drop the Ball on Unemployment?
headline.main: Did We Drop the Ball on Unemployment?
headline.print_headline: Did We Drop the Ball on Unemployment?

docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column asserts national politicians and journalists seem to have taken their focus away from jobs even though American public is overwhelmingly concerned with the issue; urges Pres Obama to fight to put unemployment at the top of the national agenda.
docs.snippet: In small-town Oregon, it’s easy to spot the country’s most pressing problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: Smart shoppers know that the remainder bin always contains bargains, assuming one is not too picky about quality. That is also true on the N.F.L. free-agent market. The Indianapolis Colts, nervous about Peyton Manning's health for their season opener Sept. 11, and about the readiness of his backups Curtis Painter and Dan Orlovsky, coaxed Kerry Collins out of retirement Wednesday. Collins, who is now so gray and grizzled that he resembles Richard Crenna in the Rambo movies, may think that backing up Manning is just like retirement, but these are unusual circumstances.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week's Metropolitan cover article, ''The High Price of Looking Like a Woman,'' by Laura Rena Murray, spurred outrage and debate online about the widespread use of silicone injections by transgender women -- many of whom turn to so-called pumpers who practice illegally and often end up disfiguring their clients' bodies. Following are excerpts from the discussion on NYTimes.com. Readers also reacted to Neil Genzlinger's City Critic column about New York practices he would like to see ticketed. This was heartbreaking. I hope that an investigation and crackdown is launched to prosecute these hack ''doctors.'' It is so wrong, on every level.

headline.main: Yearning for Curves, but at What Cost?
